title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" requires the Commissioner of Social Security to provide information on deceased individuals for use by federal and state agencies administering benefits programs. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement safeguards to protect information from unauthorized use or disclosure by federal or state agencies administering benefits programs, including the Do Not Pay system. Agencies can cooperate with the Commissioner, including their Inspector General, and reimburse for services provided. The Commissioner of Social Security can collaborate with agencies, including their Inspector General, to implement safeguards and receive reimbursement for services provided, ensuring no conflict with their duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can cooperate with federal agencies to use information on deceased individuals for specific purposes, as long as it aligns with their duties. This collaboration includes operating the Do Not Pay system to prevent improper payments. The agency can use the Do Not Pay system to compare death information with personally identifiable information and share the results with authorized federal or state agencies. The Commissioner can disclose personally identifiable information from the working system to authorized Federal or State agencies for proper payments, tax administration, or debt collection purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can disclose personally identifiable information to authorized agencies for payment certification, disbursement, tax administration, debt collection, and law enforcement purposes. Additionally, similar arrangements can be made with States for sharing information on deceased individuals. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with States for specific purposes, such as benefit pension plans or retirement systems for state employees. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with States or political subdivisions for statistical purposes and research activities, subject to safeguards for protection. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with Federal and State agencies for statistical purposes and research activities, with necessary safeguards in place. The amendments made by this subsection to certain sections of the Social Security Act will be repealed five years after enactment. Additionally, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace "Secretary of Health and Human Services" with "Commissioner of Social Security" in specified subparagraphs. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for use by Federal agencies, including State agencies, as authorized in the Social Security Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review non-Federal sources of death data for Federal agency use, analyzing accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review non-Federal sources of death data for Federal agency use, analyzing accessibility, cost, security, reliability, and potential alternate sources of death data. A report will be submitted to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of this Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of this Act, recommending whether to extend agency access to death data from the Commissioner of Social Security. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 amends the act to improve the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on maintaining databases of beneficiary information within 6 months of the enactment of the section. The Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance to agencies operating databases of beneficiary information, ensuring access to death databases within 6 months of enactment. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government within 1 year of enactment. Additionally, a report to Congress on improving data matching for payments to deceased individuals must be submitted within 270 days of the enactment of this section. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant Federal agencies, States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations, will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days to improve data matching with the Federal Government for deceased individuals receiving benefits under federally funded programs. Tribal organizations providing federally funded benefits will enhance data matching with the Federal Government for deceased individuals receiving benefits. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit an annual report to Congress for five years on the implementation of this section, including recommendations. Definitions for 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are provided in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including data on individuals not receiving benefits under titles II or XVI of the Social Security Act. The plan should include a procedure for identifying extremely elderly individuals. The plan required under subsection (a) shall include a procedure for identifying extremely elderly individuals who are still alive according to the records of the Social Security Administration and verifying the accuracy of this information, as well as improved policies for correcting erroneous records. Improved policies and procedures for identifying and correcting errors in records, including identifying individuals listed incorrectly as dead or alive, and allowing individuals to report potential errors. This includes improving procedures for the Numerical Identification System and death data. The Commissioner of Social Security shall implement improved policies and procedures to identify and correct errors in records, including statistical analysis of death data to estimate erroneous records and recommendations for legislation within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Commissioner of Social Security will implement a plan to identify and correct errors in records, including estimating the number of erroneous records and making recommendations for legislation within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
